First, SocGen.

11:20 am
BE

The British exit from the EU comes at a time when the property cycle looks
set to reverse under a fast-rising speculative supply. While the final
outcome is unpredictable, the past two cycles and our rental value
forecasts suggest property prices may fall 25% peak-to-trough this time,
and that share prices could still have 19% to give back. We detail below
why we fear the recent sector rebound could simply be a dead cat bounce.

BE

deadcat

PM

People bought into the drop, thinking it was a dip

11:21 am
BE

According to PricewaterhouseCoopers, Brexit should cause a serious shock to
the UK economy, which could lead to between 70k and 100k fewer jobs in the financial
services sector and 950k job losses overall. On the basis of 50k job losses in London, in
line with previous cycles, office rent values should decrease by 24%, on our computation.
In both the past two crises (1989-92 and 2007-09), the market priced in a 28-29% fall in
capital values. If that scenario repeats itself, UK share prices should fall 43% from the
October 2015 peak to trough, or another 27% from here.

PM

This point about an export boom in jobs is real enough. My sister in law, Maggie immediately bought a house in France last week and put her house in Bradford up for sale. She's actually leaving the country.

BE

Bear in mind we're largely talking commercial property here though.

11:23 am
PM

Yeah, sure

BE

(Though the comment threads all over the website don't seem to care much for that distinction. HPL outbreaks everywhere.)

BE

Back to SocGen.

11:24 am
BE

The bad
However, on our forecasts, capital values should ‘drop only’ 25% peak-to-
trough (to a 6.5% equivalent yield, up 160bp), which implies a 19% sector decline. We
have lowered our EPRA NAV estimates by 17% over 2016-19e, and cutting our target
prices by 14% on average. We are downgrading GPOR to Sell (from Hold), and LAND and
BLND to Hold (from Buy). We maintain our Buy on HMSO for its euro exposure and fast-
growing dividend, and reiterate our Sell rating on INTU, as it may have to raise equity. Our
NAV estimates are now 19% and 31% below consensus for 2016 and 2017.

BE

The good
The stress in GBP credit spreads has been contained to a 13bp hike, while
they fell by 6bp in EUR. The BoE will ‘probably’ ease over the summer, and it suggested
that QE could be reinstituted. The low cost of funding is very likely to provide a floor to
capital values and share prices. Based on our triple-metric cash/NAV approach, our
valuations imply an average 12m TSR of 10%, of which 4% is dividends.

BE

The risk
Bad news creates uncertainties. The first is the framework and timing of the UK
exit, the second is the impact on the economy, and how badly it would affect London
house prices. The positives expected from the BoE might be only a short relief ahead of a
declining rental cycle, poor economic data points and consensus downgrades.

11:25 am
BE

Here come the downgrades.

BE

British Land Company PLC (BLND:LSE): Last: 541.50, down 23.5 (-4.16%), High: 554.00, Low: 536.50, Volume: 3.95m
11:25 am
Hammerson PLC (HMSO:LSE): Last: 495.60, down 13.4 (-2.63%), High: 510.50, Low: 487.60, Volume: 1.02m
Land Securities Group PLC (LAND:LSE): Last: 931.00, down 49 (-5.00%), High: 970.00, Low: 923.50, Volume: 1.80m
Intu Properties PLC (INTU:LSE): Last: 270.30, down 8.5 (-3.05%), High: 276.60, Low: 266.60, Volume: 2.36m
11:26 am
PM

sheesh

BE

You'll also want to hear from Mike Prew though, who's the Reit godfather.

BE

Jefferies, of course.

11:27 am
BE

LAND and BLND shares were -6% and -7%, respectively, yesterday for a reason. It
might not be a rerun of 2008 with banks better capitalised to the tune of £150bn, but 2016
is shaping up to be a rerun of 2007. With real estate open-ended funds having switched
from monthly to weekly valuations and cut pricing by -5% last week given the uncertainty
of real estate valuation since the Brexit vote. Standard Life Investments (SLI) yesterday gated its £2.9bn Standard Life Investments UK Real Estate Fund by suspending dealing in response to a spike in redemption requests following the EU referendum result (CoStar). The problem is the liquidity mismatch between cash/near cash (REIT shares) and bricks and mortar. These open-ended funds own c.5% of the UK commercial real estate market (REITs = 12%) vs. 2% in 2007 (see over) and the fund flows are correlated with property values - perhaps less so the prime end of the market, which overseas capital repriced post QE (2009-2012), but in the high yielding secondary and regional markets. The positive difference is that the BOE had advised these funds, which are structurally inappropriate for purpose, to boost liquidity levels from 3%-5% of AuM to greater than 20%. The problem is that with long lead times into committed real estate purchases, the drop off in inflows and then redemptions forces these funds to eat into their liquidity buffer, which is widely warehoused in REIT shares (for the 3%-4% dividend yield vs. cash at 0.5% - and probably 0% soon - and REIT shares should perform broadly like leveraged real estate to cushion the cash drag on fund performance).

No one knows how this phony war in real estate markets will end up, but valuers are not
inserting an ‘uncertainty clause’, instead adding a lower level of caveat with an ‘advisory
note’. Brexit has affected the real estate market but there is no transactional evidence that the
UK's valuation methodology can rely on. The likelihood is a one-off Article 50 devaluation
when enacted, but it could be delayed until 2017, and the market is left with the high-
water valuation mark e.g. Bluewater at 4% (July 2014). Until then, there is no certainty of
commercial property valuations.

BE

Now we have the first example of a UK real estate investment fund stopping
investors taking their money out post the Brexit vote. The SLI £2.9bn fund invests in a mixture
of commercial real estate in the UK, and in a statement said: “The suspension was requested
to protect the interests of all investors in the fund and to avoid compromising investment returns
from the range, mix and quality of assets within the portfolio ... The fund continues to offer a
stable and secure income return with a distribution yield of circa 3.86% ... the selling process for
real estate can be lengthy as the fund manager needs to offer assets for sale, find prospective
buyers, secure the best price and complete the legal transaction ... there is a risk that the fund
manager will not achieve the best deal for investors in the fund, including those who intend to
remain invested over the medium to long-term ... The suspension will end as soon as practicable,
and will be formally reviewed at least every 28 days.” REIT shares are now in a period
of NAV uncertainty with downside risk as funds are forced sellers ahead of the
interim earnings (HMSO 25/7, SGRO 26/7, UTG 26/7, CAPO 26/7, intu 28/7). Our ready
reckoner for basket casing REIT shares is to half the trailing NAV (i.e. LAND 717p vs. a share
price of 1007p; BLND 460p vs. 570p) as the sector traded at a 50% discount to spot NAVs in
2008 but REITs are leveraged 30%-40% rather than 60%-70%. We used a 40% discount in
our post referendum ‘Life after Leave’ (24 June) but the rating risk has risen on the SLI news.
It’s still not safe to go back into the water, even with these dividend yields (but how safe
are they?), but it must be getting closer. LAND and BLND share prices (see over) are now
both within 5p of the PT level we set in our last major downgrade memorandum ('Red in
the Rainbow'; 25 April 2016).

BE

Sorry about the duff formatting. It's worth persevering with.

11:28 am
BE

And contact Jefferies directly for those valuation charts.

Legal & General Group PLC (LGEN:LSE): Last: 175.10, down 11.9 (-6.36%), High: 183.60, Low: 173.30, Volume: 17.47m
11:30 am
PM

Ouch

BE

We have Jefferies playing the "uncertainty" card on L&G this morning.

BE

The growth trajectory for the group appears clouded in the short to medium
term by uncertain financial markets that could delay pension de-risking,
reduce protection volumes and stall direct investments in LGC. While the
current level of dividend is secured by stable back book cash generation and
resilient solvency, dividend growth from here appears unclear. We downgrade
to Hold.

11:31 am
BE

Current dividend underpinned by back book: Ongoing back book earnings are
unlikely to deteriorate rapidly even in volatile financial markets given the stickiness of the
pension scheme driven assets in both Retirement and LGIM; an advantage over savings and asset management models that keeps the current absolute level of dividends secure.

BE

But growth trajectory unclear: The unravelling of financial markets, most notably
“lower for longer “UK and US interest rates in combination with the risk of a deteriorating
credit environment in the future, likely higher inflation and volatile equity markets, clouds
the growth trajectory at L&G. For instance bulk annuities could be delayed or rendered
unaffordable by rising pension deficits, protection growth reduced by falling mortgage
volumes and LGC direct investments stalled in uncertain property markets.

BE

Slowing dividend growth: We reduce our growth assumptions for the business units
(notably bulk annuities, protection and LGC) with 2018F earnings -9% vs last published and
dividend growth rate from 7%/6%/7% 2016/17/18 to 7%/5%/4% reflecting the uncertainty
in the earnings trajectory and limited upside via higher payouts given the lower-than-sector
average 1.5x cash cover.

11:32 am
BE

Solvency resilient: While the SII ratio at the group has remained resilient in volatile
financial markets (S2 ratio now at 156% vs 140% threshold), our stress test based on a further 25bps fall in rates, 20% fall in equity markets, +50bps increase in spreads would take the ratio down to 149%.

BE

We value the stock using a multi-stage income model cross-checked by DDM increasing
our CoC from 10% to 11% given current volatile markets and higher equity risk premium.
While likely oversold short term on Brexit, the fundamental growth story is likely to come
under scrutiny over the next 12 months. The stock is trading at 9.5x 2017F, 8% dividend
yield vs an average of 9-10x for UK life names, 7.5x 2017F PE 7.0% dividend yield European insurers. Upside risks include recovery in financial markets and growth, rapid international expansion, large profitable deals to boost cash generation.

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

11:33 am
BE

As I say, we have a large amount of sellside. About three-quarters of it downgrades, all saying uncertainty is difficult to model.

BE

Pru? Pru.

Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,200, down 59.6 (-4.73%), High: 1,261, Low: 1,200, Volume: 2.99m
11:33 am
PM

Sheesh

BE

JP Morgan says switch into AIA (which would be part of Pru if shareholders weren't such a bunch of whining children).

BE

AIA more attractive than PRU. Both AIA and PRU have a progressive
dividend policy, increasing DPS every year (AIA by 15% p.a. vs. PRU by 5%
p.a.). In our view, both insurers’ future capital management policy should be
based on their existing solvency framework (PRU: EU solvency II vs. AIA: HK
solvency standard). HK’s solvency calculation is based on prudent HK reserves
and the company’s capital is purely based on equity. Thus, AIA’s ~10%
leverage ratio demonstrates its low leverage versus PRU’s 33% leverage ratio
(JPMe). Also, while AIA allocates 40% of fixed-income AUM to government
and government agency bonds, PRU’s liability matching is largely based on
corporate bonds. We estimate corporate bond exposure as a percentage of NAV
to be 200% for AIA vs. 446% for PRU.

11:34 am
BE

PRU’s balance sheet and growth prospects. PRU reported an economic
solvency ratio of 257% as at FY13, and a 193% Solvency II ratio as at FY15.
We expect this to drop by c.24% to 168% as of 1 July 2016 (incl. recent $1bn
debt issuance). We believe 1) PRU’s UK SII ratio is 112%, below its hurdle rate
of 130%, which could trigger a capital injection, 2) a large part of PRU’s capital
is “soft” (i.e. proxy VIF) which isn’t fungible, and 3) any contagion into UK
credit and/or US equities/credit would further weaken its balance sheet as PRU
remains heavily exposed to these factors. In terms of growth, we believe that
PRU’s UK and M&G are shrinking; the US is being impacted by DOL, and in
Asia, although the long-term prospects appear intact, we expect short-term
headwinds from Indonesia/Singapore to continue with lower HK sales.

Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 1,391, down 44.26 (-3.08%), High: 1,458, Low: 1,326, Volume: 1.53m

BE

Have some comment anyway. Davy.

11:41 am
BE

The poor sentiment brought about by the UK’s decision in June
to leave the EU will continue to weigh on names in the UK
home building sector. However, H1 saw a very strong
environment for the builders, with increasing margins and no
weakness in the run-up to the referendum. According to
Persimmon, it is still too early to judge the market reaction in
the new homes market.

BE

Robust volume and profit growth seen in first half
Persimmon completed 7,238 units in the first six months of 2016, 6% ahead of the same
period last year. This was 1% ahead of our estimates, driven by strong demand and low
borrowing costs.
The run-up to the EU referendum saw good customer demand, with private sales rates
1% ahead of last year. Visitor numbers were 8% stronger in the first half of the year
compared to H1 2015 and sales rates (at 0.75) were 4% higher. ASP was £205,500,
c.5% higher than the same period last year and 3% ahead of our estimates.
The company has made excellent progress on profitability, and the H1 margin will be
ahead of the 23% seen in H2 2015 (Davy H1 2016 operating margin estimate 21.8%).
Overall, H1 operating profit should be c.10% ahead of our estimates.

BE

Persimmon closed H1 with an order book of £1.36bn; this was broadly in line with the
same point last year and represents over five months of supply. The private ASP within
the forward sales is £227,000, roughly 6% above last year’s number.

The group added 7,100 plots to the land bank over the first six months, slightly below
replacement (7,238 units). With the lower replacement rate, and despite paying over
£330m in dividends in April, Persimmon saw net cash increase to £462m at the end of
June. This should give investors confidence in the capital return plan over the medium
term, outside of Brexit fears.

Regarding the possible fallout from the EU referendum, the company commented that it
is too soon to judge the effect of Brexit on the business or the industry.

[Modwen's] interim results show trading profits ahead of our expectations, and NAV growth of 1% over the period was low, but in line with expectations. EPRA NAV of 451p (our forecast 448p) reflected a flat performance in the investment portfolio, and a c.10% write-down in the value of the New Covent Garden Market asset (we had forecast a 13% fall in 1H16A, and expect a further 13% in 2H16E). We believe negative sentiment towards Central London residential assets has resulted in an over-reaction in the share price, but without a whole/partial sale of the NCGM site, it is difficult to see the shares re-rate upwards in the short term. Longer term we still see value and maintain our Buy rating.

11:52 am
undefined
BE

BE

So somewhere near the start of the show, about seven or eight hours ago, someone mentioned Whitbread.

11:53 am
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 3,386, down 116.69 (-3.33%), High: 3,450, Low: 3,283, Volume: 592.88k
BE

Which is another "uncertainty" downgrade.

BE

This time from Barclays.

11:54 am
BE

Brexit has raised a pall of uncertainty that hangs over underwhelming hotels and milky coffee.

BE

We downgrade to Underweight with a new 3220p PT. We cut forecasts 11% by 2018
and assume a de-rating to 13.5x PE (vs 12x in 2011/12 during the last UK RevPAR
slowdown). As we highlighted in All about RevPAR (published 15/6/2016) we
considered Whitbread to be one of the most negatively affected Leisure stocks in the
event of Brexit due to the exposure to business investment. While the shares have
suffered since, we see further downside risks. Barclays economists have significantly
cut business investment growth assumptions (see Global Economics Weekly: A
“Leave” into uncertainty 24/6/16) on the back of which we now expect RevPAR to be
-3.2% this year and -1.6% in 2017/18. Despite assuming £27m cost savings, our
new forecasts are 6% and 10% below Thomson One consensus this year and next.

BE

Risks to our UW thesis... 1) Our economists’ business investment forecasts may
th
be too cautious – while the IoD survey (27 June) provides some supportive
evidence for businesses cutting investment, there are many unknowns at this
early stage; 2) Bigger cost cuts - Our forecasts mirror the quantum of cost cuts
seen during the more severe 2008-9 downturn when the hotel and restaurants
businesses were merged but we believe savings could be greater under new CEO,
Alison Brittain, as the group is already in the midst of a cost cutting programme.;
3) Short-term trading may not be too bad – London should see more inbound
leisure tourism due to £ weakness with Kayak and Cheapflights reporting a surge
in searches for trips to UK. This should help the c17% of Whitbread’s rooms in
London (though only c50% exposure to Leisure). In July the Ramadan timing
shift and Farnborough air show should also support London performance.
Meanwhile over the summer, leisure travel in the UK regions can be supported by
more ‘staycations’ due to the weaker £. We expect the real signs of corporate
capex weakness to be more obvious from September.

11:55 am
BE

...but it could also be worse: Our downside case is similar to 2008-9 at 2700p
(assumes 11.5x PE vs 8.8x in 2008/9). Unlike 2008-9, we believe the structural
growth story is less supportive today with Costa’s UK net system growth running
at 6.4% vs 21% in 09 and we see risk that the group slows the hotel rollout since
c35% of openings are extensions.

undefined

BE

Here's the Liberum sector overview.

11:58 am
BE

Post-Brexit we revisit our forecasts in view of the more
uncertain outlook. While the impact on consumer spending
is yet unknown, we look at all our top-line assumptions and
the impact of imported inflation. We identify those most at
risk of further de-rating, but find some shares oversold.
Those companies with sustainable organic growth, margin
upside and benefit from structural or secular trends are our
preferred plays. Balance sheets across the sector are
stronger than in the downturn of 2008-2012, therefore we
advocate selective buying opportunities.

BE

Top picks

BE

Reflecting on the prelims and Brexit risks, we believe near-term
headwinds have strengthened. FY16 performance suggested that
revenues may be more volatile than we had expected and margin
expansion has likely been pushed further out. We still acknowledge the
company's strong market shares, improving multi-channel offering and
the longer-term growth opportunity in Services. However, we see further
downside risk before the shares make any substantial gains. We cut our
EPS forecasts, reset our TP to 200p and move to SELL (from BUY).

12:01 pm
BE

Weak FY16 Health & Hygiene sales due to a poor flea season, may reflect a
more volatile top line than we had expected. Further, post Brexit uncertainty
may see consumers trading down or seeking greater value, in particular
through online competitors. Reflecting this, we lower our LFL Merchandise
growth forecasts to: FY17 0.5% (prev. +2.0%), FY18 +2.0% (prev. +2.5%),
FY19 +2.5% (as previous). There is some revenue offset from recent referral
vet practice acquisitions.
20% of COGS are purchased in US$, which relates to accessories. We
forecast FX impacts to drive a -40bps fall in Merchandise gross margin.
Services margin expansion is progressing slower than we had forecast. At
the same time, the strategy of investing for growth (staff, multi-channel,
product offering) continues. As a result, potential operating margin expansion
is unlikely until at least FY19E. These pressures lead us to lower our EPS
forecasts by-4%, -8% and -11% in FY17E, FY18E and FY19E respectively.

BE

We reset our TP to 200p (previously 335p), implying a calendar 2016 PER of
13x, which is supported by our DCF and ROIC/WACC valuations. There
remain some clear positives to the investment case including, the company’s
leading market shares, strong customer service, improving multi-channel offer
and the long-term growth opportunities in the vet and grooming markets.
However, we believe the heightened downside risks over the medium-term as
outlined above, are likely to see further pressure on the shares at this stage.
